WRITING.TEXT: That's fair, I've had the same problem with the Splinters rune on Poison Dart. My reasoning is that the Shadow DH really doesn't give a crap about much beyond killing Guardians as quickly and as efficiently as possible. When you kill the RG, the rift is over, period. Besides, with the spread you're still just as likely to have two blades flying off into nowhere if you stand too far away, only now it's every single shot instead of just the last one.

I don't think the set dungeons are designed to be a tutorial on how to play the set. It's an experts-only level of play for people who know the set so well that they can even play it on a handicap. Maybe it's because I beat most of these dungeons pre-nerf and want them to stay hard to keep the cool wings exclusive ;)

I've said it before, but I feel like the PTR is missing a golden opportunity to put the DH in the meta, but in an interesting and unconventional way: making the Shadow's set worth a damn as the premier single-target DPS build currently occupied by the gen Monk. The only thing holding the Ninja back is the monk's ability to attack so crazy fast that BotS stacks ramp up fast enough to compensate and then surpass Impale's slower spike damage. Holy Point Shot is a step in the right direction, but if all three daggers could hit the same target it would allow the DH's own Bane to compete with the monk and stay ahead. Forget about AoE; if the HPS was redesigned to fire off three daggers in succession rather than in a spread, it would IMO synergize nicely with the Ninja's focus on boss-killing and allow it to take that coveted 4th place in the meta.

It's a break from the grind; I'm also looking forward to the Challenge Rifts. It's almost like playing Diablo 3: Puzzle Mode, because a lot of the dungeons can't be beaten with ever-increasing numbers. You have to experiment with unconventional builds and playstyles, and that's appealing to me. It's one of the few things in Diablo that actually requires a brain beyond rote memorization. Even with the hard ones, I appreciate the challenge and that moment of satisfaction when you finally beat it after banging your head against the wall repeatedly. The high isn't all that different from beating a boss for the first time in Dark Souls, or another similarly hard game.

I understand it's all just a matter of perspective, but I actually didn't have a problem with Wastes. Once I figured out using the Gangway rune kept enemies from touching me, it just became a matter of keeping that up at all times and resisting the urge to WW everywhere. I beat it in like two more tries and is one of the few set dungeons I regularly do from time to time just for fun :) Seriously, it's a blast!
...for twelve years -_-
Nor are they consummate.
That's actually pretty fly.
Guy wouldn't know majesty if it came up and bit him in the face.
That could be an idea. Like, maybe if you manage to deck them out entirely in Ancient gear, they get the immortality with or without the relic. That frees up your slot for a more interesting relic.

That's an interesting point I hadn't considered, but on reflection is that really so bad? There's only so much Hatred you can store up, so all it really means is that they aren't as resource-thirsty as DH builds tend to be. Besides, the three knives can already hit the same target (within a certain range), my idea can't do anything the current version can't except increase the effective range.

With bounties I think it would be better if you only had to do a number of bounties per act equal to the people in your party + 1. So if you're solo you'd only have to do 2 bounties to get the cache. Still not quite as efficient as splitting but it doesn't feel like a punishment at least.
Well, that explains [that](https://thechive.files.wordpress.com/2015/06/not-all-movie-credits-are-created-equal-15-photos-14.jpg?quality=85 strip=info w=600)
It's true, I was killing elites too quickly to pull off the intricate series of moves to complete the objective. Taking out the rubies made it much easier.

Granted, nobody in the entire world thinks Shadow's is a viable solo progression set, not even the devs lol. It does one non-traditional thing better than any set in the game, to the exclusion of other things. It's an experts-only playstyle, but with the right support there may just be a place for it.

That's on me for being long-winded, but it was my way of fixing S6 to make it competitive without even needing to consider LGF. The entire (Karlei's) point is to not give a shit about AoE oriented skills. The 4-man meta as of right now is 2 support characters, an AoE DPS guy, and a boss-killer. We're talking about boss-killers here :)

Weirdly misappropriated pic aside, that's a fair comparison of two good games. I'll never understand the fan war between the two games when one is free and the other has a cost/value ratio envied by 99% of the entertainment world. Don't fight, you're both pretty :)

WRITING.TITLE: Holy Point Shot suggestions
WRITING.TEXT:
Does anybody have strong thoughts on this item in the PTR? As a huge fan of the Shadow Impale DH (henceforth, "Ninja"), I'm of two minds. Clearly Blizzard wants to support this build with its own BiS quiver, and HPS in its current form is definitely a huge step up, but there is still room for improvement.
But I'm getting ahead of myself. First off, bear in mind I'm not on the PTR myself so this is all theoretical. For those who don't know, the Ninja is an astoundingly high single-target DPS build that focuses on mobility and elimination of priority targets. It suffers for AoE which is why nobody plays it much, but Holy Point Shot (a quiver on the PTR that allows Impale to throw three daggers in a cone) appears to be an effort to alleviate that.
What concerns me is that people running the Ninja build already know the AoE is butts and presumably want it to be the designated "titan-slayer" in the 4-player meta (a role currently taken by a monk with high attack speed who is able to ramp up those Bane of the Stricken stacks). More spread and having daggers flying off into nowhere is helping nobody.
Part of the solution to this is having those three daggers all able to hit the same target within a certain range, so the build essentially becomes a shotgun. It works, especially if each dagger can proc BotS, but it feels inelegant to me; the Ninja is about range and precision. Not to mention there are already more than enough melee to mid-range builds out there. My idea: instead of a spread, have HPS fire three daggers in the same direction, similar to the Splinters rune for Poison Dart but faster. In other words, less of a shotgun and more of a burst-fire rifle.
There are several benefits I can see to those willing to forgo the spread. For one, it could theoretically triple the attack speed, allowing it to compete with the generator monk for BotS stacks. Another reason is its ability to take out white mobs who get in the line of fire, a common frustration for Ninja players. The first knife takes out the mob and the other two proceed to target, like getting a pseudo-Overpenetration rune for free. Finally, it simply keeps with the spirit of a build that focuses entirely on precision and accuracy at long range.
In fact, the only downside I can see (I'm only brainstorming) other than the area damage is having to stay in place long enough to fire three daggers in succession. It's probably only a fraction of a second, but every bit counts in this game.
Anyone else have thoughts on how to make the Shadow build useful? I really, really like this build, you guys. HPS is awesome but I don't want it to be a missed opportunity :)
tl;dr: preserve the range, triple the speed and stacks, and don't emphasize area damage, and you could theoretically shake up the 4-player meta

"It's like an infinite fractal recursion, a flickering quantum state of both 'hot' and 'not'."
-Stephen Colbert

Quick correction: the Rainbow Goblin drops a portal to Whimsydale, not Whimsyshire which is only accessible via Staff of Herding. You may also want to specify that the Mace of Crows is found in a Mysterious Barrel, not a Mysterious Chest like the other items. That could lead to a lot of frustration if people don't know exactly what they're hunting for. Other than that, great guide!

I try not to let myself get carried away with nostalgia, but god damn that would be a fun world to explore. Actually, I think you just gave me a hook for a new 5e one shot, thanks for that :)
You don't happen to have any ideas on how such a campaign would play out, do you?

Sounds like you put a lot of thought into it. Few objections, though...
Story: Problem with framing Imperius as the antagonist is he's already gone through an arc, from standoffish skeptic to reluctant ally, and then to real full ally. Besides, the Diablo universe already has a ready-made antagonist with unresolved Nephalem issues in Inarius, the angelic progenitor of humanity who was last seen being taken and tortured by the minions of Hell after losing to the Nephalem hero Uldyssian.
Story Mode: It's not spelled out, but a lot of evidence suggests that Blizzard really wants to make a new hub in the Skovos Isles, the Amazon homeland and the subject of innumerable conversations between Tyrael and Lorath. I'm no Diablo expansion bookie but if I was, I'd have good odds on that.
The rest of your suggestions are kind of a pick n mix bag, but some are legitimately interesting if overly optimistic. Still though, ideas are cheap and development is not, but Blizzard has definitely *not* given up on Diablo 3. They may be taking their time on a scale slower than players want, but personally I'd rather wait to get a great product than to receive a slapdash product right now.

Or better yet, what if one click released three daggers in very rapid succession along the same trajectory, like the Splinters rune for the WD's Poison Dart? That way you preserve the range while still tripling the volume, though admittedly it would take longer to fire off and leave you flat-footed. As an added bonus, if white mobs get in the way you can clear them and still hit the boss in the same shot, almost like getting the Overpenetration rune for free.
Username almost relevant.

If all three can hit the same target then what we have is a shotgun by another name. The new meta will necessitate getting up close and personal, which aside from the fact that there are already more than enough melee and mid-range oriented builds in the game, it just doesn't feel right to me.
For one thing the Ninja as it stands now is highly mobile and able to strike from any range. The triple-strike mechanic you described would basically limit the range for max damage, thus limiting the number of places the DH can fight effectively. Second, it puts the DH in more danger for being closer to the fight when before he could just hang back and drop daggers of doom in on a Rift Guardian bogged down by a more tanky build. Finally (I admit this one is personal, but still) there's just something cathartic about the surgical precision of a single, devastating sniper shot from a full screen away, and it kinda saps that feeling to watch two more daggers flying off into nowhere, and knowing that I only have 33% accuracy with them :/
Don't get me wrong, I'll gratefully take HPS in whatever form they give us and call it a massive improvement. But as long as they're taking suggestions, I just want to keep the effective range and stack BotS bonuses quickly. If nothing else, at least narrow the spread of the two flanking daggers to make it less blunderbuss and more rifle barrel, if you understand my meaning.

I'm not on the PTR so this is all just theory, but as much as I love the Shadow Impale build getting its own BiS quiver, is the bonus of Holy Point Shot keeping with the spirit of the build? I can understand wanting to give a little more AoE but I thought that sacrificing AoE in exchange for massive single-target DPS was the whole idea, ideally a designated "titan-slayer" in the 4-player meta. To that end, the best thing HPS could possibly do is somehow increase the attack speed of Impale to really ramp up those BotS stacks.
Well that went better than expected. Be my valentine, you trolly motherfucker 3
Oh, you are just adorable :)
I'll admit, Jade Harvester kicked my butt pretty badly, I'm not much of a WD player.

Thanks for that man. I knew better than to assume the entire community was represented by the "charming" individuals trolling the sub today, and that the majority are all right people who love their game and want to share it with others. It's just... God damn, they really are out in force today :P
I did try out PoE about a year or so ago. It was all right and I certainly see the appeal, but it didn't scratch the same itch so I came back to D3. No accounting for taste, I guess. I'd be glad to give it another shot on the assumption that the community as a whole is closer to you than, say, /u/UncleDan2017

:thinking: It may cost zero dollars but if it means zero to me, that's still 0/0. :thinking:
Sarcasm aside, I don't know why there's all this bitterness. I like Diablo, I'm glad you find similar enjoyment in PoE, and that's all that needs to be said, really. I hope you enjoy your new content :)

I did say "another shot" with the implication that I played it before and just didn't care for it. It's not a bad game, it's just not fun to me personally.
And of course I know not everybody in the POE community is patronizing, a lot of really awesome and supportive people were helping me last time I played. It's just that when a whole flood of the worst of them come over to my corner of the internet just to shit all over my favorite game and call me stupid for liking it, don't be surprised if I'm kinda turned off.

Sure it's a bummer, but with the BK set it wasn't hard to keep Gangway up all the time. Combine that with Ground Stomp - Wrenching Smash and enemies just stayed stun locked long enough for me to group them up, Rend, and vaporize them with WW. It's hard but I don't think it was unfair; I've beaten that dungeon three times since then just for fun, and it's remarkably consistent once you have it down.

I appreciate that. I've been taking a lot of weirdly-placed vitriol today in my preferred brand of grind-fest ARPG. I don't know for sure which one you play but I hope you're having as great a time with it as I am with Diablo :)

Wastes remains, to date, the only set dungeon I've gone back to for fun rather than to check a box on the season journey :)

There's an interesting hypothesis that, as humans are the only creatures known to "finish" the act (other animals are known to touch themselves but not orgasm), it is at least partly a mechanism to clear out sperm that have existed past their expiration date. WRITING.TITLE: What was your tattoo idea that, in retrospect, you're glad someone talked you out of?

WRITING.TEXT: Hey man, that's all that matters, period :) Glad you're having fun

You're going to have a good early next season if they stick to the rotation and give the Crusader Akkhan's set; it's who I planned to be as well. It may not be the most powerful late-game but it offers a great deal of versatility and is perfect when you're just starting out.

I did that set-up early on in the season and hated it. Firebird is just too squishy to work well above T7 without support items. Sure it does a lot of damage but you're too reliant on finding elites to keep that burn damage high, when a good early game set would be more flexible and work with whatever hodgepodge of rares and suboptimal legendaries you happen upon first.

The trick is to not take the game too seriously ;) I'm big into theorycrafting, so pretty much if I find an item I'd like to try out, I find a way to incorporate it. I have builds that make the most use out of skills nobody even talks about in the meta, like Spike Traps and Rapid Fire. I just turn down the difficulty and see what I can do with it. Right now I have one character for each major set plus LoN, but the variations are endless.

Not exactly. Right now I have five demon hunters with unique speedfarming and progression variations for each, depending on whatever I want to play on a given day. I'm one of those infuriatingly inefficient people who's more concerned with variety and that nebulous concept of "fun", but the point is that even after trimming down the unnecessary characters from my Hero List I can still think of way more than five directions to take one character :)

WRITING.TITLE: Armory Question
WRITING.TEXT:
I've been advocating the Armory feature since forever and am so glad it's being added! Just a quick question for those of you on the PTR: let's say I have two demon hunters. The female saves a build that has a Manticore but switches to Yang's instead. The male then takes that same Manticore from the stash and equips it. Where does the Manticore go if the female goes back to that first build? Does the male end up empty-handed?
Has anyone experimented with any other unusual circumstances concerning the Armory? Thanks!

In that first push to 70, most agree that having a slower weapon that hits harder is preferable. This is because you depend a lot on your resource (Fury, in your case) and attacking faster tends to just mean running out faster, so attack speed in those cases is more of a liability unless you depend on your resource generating attacks.
If nothing else, it's just one more reason I'm glad the Armory is coming in the next patch. Makes it much easier to just swap it out for a couple of rifts if I get bored in the solo progression.

Vyr's is easy too, if you're used to the playstyle, but steer clear of DMO unless you like the idea of banging your head against the wall for three hours.

It will always be two parties. If (hypothetically) the Libertarians got enough of the Republican vote to elect a president, the Republicans would just die out as everybody jumped ship and we'd end up with Libertarians vs. Democrats. It's not a matter of politics, it's simply math and the psychology of strategically voting for who has the best chance of beating the opponent, not necessarily your first choice.
That's why I don't joke about people's names. Sabrina has already been 'the Teenage Witch', and Malcolm has already been "in the middle" their entire lives; all it does is turn you into that guy.

There have been quite a few changes since Season 2; the power creep is real. If you haven't yet, go to the Ruins of Sescheron in Act 3 and find Kanai's Cube, the update of D2's Horadric Cube. It's basically three new gear slots. Each character has four class sets now, and most items have been revamped to allow for crazy damage and toughness relative to season 2, so there's no shortage of builds that can clear formerly impossible GR's.
Some tricks from back in the day are still around as well, though many are outdated or compromised. If you can find two Unity rings and the follower token of invulnerability, you can still effectively double your toughness, but new high powered jewelry sets can make it difficult to find a place for Unity.
I'm reminded of a couple of months ago when Roger Waters did a free benefit concert in Mexico City and reading "How 'bout that. Mexicans are literally not paying for The Wall."
But where would he put it all? In his house? I feel like all that air compressed in one spot would crush his body like an empty beer can.

I have pretty much no idea what you're talking about. The MPAA does indeed have strict [guidelines](http://www.filmratings.com/downloads/rating_rules.pdf) on the rating system (arbitrary though they may sometimes be), and the entire point is to allow parents the discretion to determine what kinds of films are OK for their children to watch. You can't slap a PG on Big Boob Panty Ninja 6 because they'd get sued back into the stone age. It's a matter of liability; theaters mostly prevent kids from going to R rated movies unless accompanied, but otherwise it's the parent's job to be sure their kid isn't watching something inappropriate.

Why is that a bad thing? Practically any build can get use out of Akarat's Champion as a support skill anyway; may as well have it up 100% when all you have is rares. Akkhan's may not have the highest numbers (and is certainly overdue for a tweak), but if there's one thing it does better than any set I can think of, it's versatility. No matter if the first legendary weapon/shield/bracer you find goes with Heaven's Fury, or FotH, or Condemn, or Blessed Shield, Akkhan's is *always* helping out in the background. It may not keep up in the endgame, but it's exactly what you need in the early season.

That particularly shouty girl just over her shoulder is 15-year-old Hazel Bryan, saying something to the effect of "Go home, n-----, go back to Africa." You know, real class act.
So the story goes, she started listening to MLK Jr's speeches and came around years later, calling up Elizabeth Eckford in the 1960's to apologize. They've since met and even been interviewed on Oprah, though a lot of evidence suggests Bryan was only trying to cover up or downplay her own involvement rather than aiming for genuine reconciliation.
It turns out what people mean when they say "racism is bad" is "being called racist is bad"
We're moving in excess of 7 miles per hour! Jesus, take the wheel!

I've actually been thinking a bit lately about what makes a "good" starter set. It has to function well enough on its own without other support items, and it has to gel with a wide variety of whatever miscellaneous skills you do find gear for during that initial push. Akkhan's and IK are probably the most perfect starters out there, while Firebird (whatever else can be said of it in the meta) is a terrible pick.

The way I see it, the only people who are going to see this are the fans, and the fans will always find something to piss and moan about. I don't know yet if it will have a PG-13 or R rating, but my advice would be to spring for the R because there's no point in watering down the material just to make it accessible to a teenage audience that probably doesn't exist.

Just wanted to point out that 'addiction' gets thrown around a lot as a term. The thing that makes something a physiological addiction and not just a psychological compulsion (like when someone is "addicted" to gaming or the internet) is a real, measurable and detrimental effect on the body when taken away: withdrawal. Drug and alcohol addiction may not be caused by an invader but similar dynamics are at play.
You know you're not beholden to the starter set, right? Just play the class with the build you want to play and use the starter set to quickly farm the gear you need.

I figure either it's a phase she'll grow out of or she's genuinely serious about it, but either way I'm going to be supportive and try not to make a big deal out of it. Listening to a 13 year old's drama bullshit is exhausting enough already lol.

I'd never be more happy to be proven wrong, but the idea of one "cure for cancer" forgets that cancer is a broad term describing dozens of different kinds of related disorders, each with different underlying complications that makes a single cure rather unlikely.

The most embarrassing moment of my entire Rock Band playing life was the time I missed a note on Silver during a FBFC attempt -_- I was playing drums.

I know that Mal- in general is a Latin-based prefix typically going before "bad" things: malevolent, malicious, malodorous, etc.
Pretty much just from the name you could see the heel-turn coming a mile away :P

LoN isn't getting any changes in the patch notes, and it would be insane if it did. Primal gear is designed to be too rare to reliably incorporate into anyone's build, so LoN will still work off of Ancient as before. Primals in this case would just be Ancient+

The direct tying of sheet DPS to weapon damage has been a common complaint of D3 since... well, always. There's no fixing that without going in and redrawing the entire formula for DPS calculation, and at that point you're better off just making a new game. Weapons don't need to be primal for the same reason that *any* item doesn't need to be primal: it's not like the Ancient gear is going anywhere. There are seasons I don't even find the normal Ancient weapon I want. You can't account for RNG, you can only play the odds. Sic semper erat.

You know, I'll say The Simpsons as both answers.
It's been nothing short of a cultural institution for more than one generation at this point. As a kid what drew me in (as well as I would imagine most of my age bracket) was not the acerbic pop culture satire or sharp writing, but rather the fact that there was a cartoon with violence, family dysfunction played for laughs, and a smartass kid that sassed authority figures and got away with it. What? It's OK, we were kids!
So episodes that showcased the less mature humor ("Bart the General", "Some Enchanted Evening") that I considered the best at the time, I go back and consider kinda lacking as an adult. Meanwhile the boring episodes to kid me ("Life On The Fast Lane") had a wit I couldn't then appreciate, and tend to hold up a little better. So yeah, taken as a whole the show has been a series of ups and downs that has remained consistently above average, I just learned to appreciate it in different ways as I got older.

I've said this before on another thread, but...

Sarah, the final boss of this movie is David Bowie's alarmingly prominent crotch bulge. You can't possibly understand the forces at work here. But sure, let's send the teenage girl.
Jesus, Billy and Mandy is on Boomerang now? I felt old enough watching Pirates of Dark Water (wow, speaking of obscure shows that still hold up)
Looking back, a lot of mediocre shows had such kickass openings that I hardly noticed, and Thundercats is my prime example. Well, that and Beetlejuice. God, that intro...
